title: Patch Chat with the Playtest Team - 6.23, Shyvana, Anivia, and Malzahar mini-updates
body:
Hey guys! Welcome to Patch Chat, a Dev Corner thread we make to talk about our new patches every two weeks: http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-623-notes

I'm Aesah on Riot's Playtest Team, a group of Diamond+ players who play with the new champions, reworks, balance tweaks, items, and map updates before they are released. It's our job to the test the changes that our designers come up with and ensure that we're introducing positive changes to LoL in terms of both balance and fun. We'll be watching this thread to answer as many questions as we can.

While we're still waiting to see how the crazy updates in 6.22 shake out, but 6.23 brings some new interesting additions. The biggest one of note is Shyvana, who can now spit fireballs after ulting to play up her dragon fantasy. Anivia's control mage aspects are emphasized at the cost of some of her burst, while Malzahar's voidlings should have more clarity. Out fo the assassin update, Akali in particular was struggling and recieved some buffs. Shen recieved small defensive stat buffs as well. A few underused items in Blade of the Ruined King, Guinsoo's Rageblade, and Sterak's Gage were improved and will be a bit more appealing to champions that were considering them before. And of course, we're still working on improving the new client!

All of us on the Playtest Team are avid gamers so feel free to talk to us as fellow LoL players!

Adam "Afic" Cohen

Akali's new passive being useless only applies if you can't land two autoattacks, but given the increased reliability on W that seems fairly unlikely. We were definitely off-base on exactly how powerful the W would be though and released her too weak, hence buffs in 6.23. I expect this to be enough, but as someone with hundreds of Akali games myself, I'll be watching her closely to see if more are needed.

About Shyvana I'm not an expert there but her new dragon E gives her additional power while she's being kited.

Akali is not in a state where number changes are going to fix her. She is having mechanical issues. Against competent opponents, they will not wait around Akali's shroud for her cooldowns, so shroud working is not as great as you would think it is. Especially given her dashing nature, her shroud doesn't follow with her hence it's not exactly working at full effect. Her shroud works if the opponent just sits in the shroud expecting to duel her one on one, but in practice, no competent player is going to do that. They will move away from shroud and kite.

While Akali sits in shroud waiting for cooldowns for a second rotation, the target can move away from shroud since it's stationary. Hence Akali has to dash again inorder to stick onto the target but now she is forced out of her shroud and can't wait for her rotations anymore. if she stays in the shroud, the target just escapes out of her dash range, hence she cannot re-engage for a second rotation. This just seems counter-intuitive to her whole playstyle, which is to stick to targets. The ultimate range nerf also doesn't help with this as well. In earlier seasons, this shroud gameplay worked much better because she had better picking power with the original ultimate range in combination of her shroud. Given the original bursty nature of her ultimate, lowering the range to 700 made sense since it could be used to train a target down, R again and again and not spacing out R's to proc her Q's. But now since the bursty nature of her ultimate is removed, it makes more sense to space out her R's with triggering her Q's hence restoring the original ultimate range would help facilitate the intended playstyle much more better.

Akali's winrate for both top and mid before the update was a solid ~50%. She is far weaker overall in all aspects kit wise. Again, as you said, shroud working doesn't make up how much power Akali lost as a result and the winrate shows this. 

Akali is now all about relying on triggering her Q and passive as her main source of damage, not her ultimate. Given the ultimate does negligible damage now compared to before, is there any point in the ultimate doing damage to begin with? Would it be better to completely shift off the damage of the ultimate and boost it's utility nature such as the range? This would give Akali the tools to achieve her intended playstyle of using R's to trigger Q's/passive. Keeping the damage on the ultimate doesn't help Akali do anything because R spamming doesn't work anymore, and it feels like it's leftover power that should be re-allocated somewhere else.

Why are you changing Anivia? Do high ELO players such as yourselves believe she's too strong? Do high ELO players such as yourselves believe the new one is nice? The official justifications given for changes are always BS. In this case, everything that was changed, from the initial non-instant R to now has been because R+E is apparently unfair. Did you see Anivia everywhere? Insight from the people who actually allow the changes to be made would be useful.

I worked on the Anivia changes and was traveling for the holidays, so direct all blame in my direction in regards to this team :)

Anyways:

* She is supposed to have a vulnerable laning phase, and that just wasn't true. She generally won or had a skill matchup into everything because she was a jack of all trades that was better than almost all. 

* Most mages have set-up to their 1shot combos. Obviously their are outliers to this (hello {{champion:134}}) but generally if you get 1shotted and there was nothing you can do about it other than "stay outside of this champion's range of threat or get instagibbed" it leaves the designer with very little wiggle room to adjust power

* her itemization leads her to being much less vulnerable than other champions: on top of her passive she almost always builds Seraph+Archangel, so she was insane at itemizing for almost every scenario. Even when an LB or Syndra bursts you, they've generally used their ultimates and have itemized damage. Anivia wasn't gated by having to build full damage items nor was she committing any cooldowns. Laning against her post-6 turned into "I get shoved out and die because of this undodgable combo" or "I win this all-in but she eggs". 

If she is very weak (which sentiment currently seems to be, but data-driven is always ideal) then she can be buffed in several different ways that I've discussed with the designer. The point of making changes of this magnitude is that they're sustainable changes, and I do believe these are sustainabble -- even if she released weak in the short term.

6. Support experiment. Do you have any analysis or hypothesis on the experiment? For me, I have couple of reason why players don't pick support.

Losing as support felt awful because you had no control over it, totally reliant on the carries to not messed up. No impact beside vision and peeling. Reason why most people don't want to ranked as support because they can't control their team or map. Need objectives for support.
    3. Too little damage and squishy. Late game, support get destroy quick and can't output noticeable damage as other squishy or tank. Support can't 1v1 and they can't ward in safely without escort.
